reviewText:
I'll preface this review by saying that I love survival horror games. I've spent several thousands of hours playing and watching many games of the genre, including the Silent Hill, Resident Evil, Alone in the Dark and Fatal Frame series, so it goes without saying I have no problem with dated controls or graphics.

I was really excited for Back in 1995, and I wanted to like it. I was practically waiting down to the hour for it to be out on Steam. I already knew it was going to be a short game, as stated in the info on steam: Approximate playtime is 2-3 hours".

First to put things straight
date: that approximation is VERY off. I completely finished everything the game had to offer in about 1.25 hours
recommended: this is INCLUDING a section that had no gameplay and was just a set of text commentary. I already expected the game to be short and wouldn't have had a problem with it were it not for my second problem with the game:\n\nSubstance. The game lacks any real substance in terms of plot
hoursPlayed: story devices or a conclusion. Most of the game is spent plodding along following instructions and tidbits of newspaper clippings and notes which establish a hint at some sort of extra layer to the story that is never quite fulfilled. The living characters are basically props
voteText: they offer nothing to the story and have no characterisation or personality. Even the unvoiced protagonist has barely anything to offer. It's a shame because after the false ending the game looked like it was going to take a turn for the interesting
helpfulPercent: before being cut short and ending the game (which by the way
votesHelpful: is basically just developer commentary which while cool doesn't really make up for the lack of conclusion). This game really excels at getting your hopes up for some excitement
votesTotal: then letting you down abruptly.\n\nIn terms of audio
votesFunny: I was pretty underwhelmed. There was very little sound in the game
commentsCount: no change of footsteps whatsoever no matter what ground you walk on. The music was
column17: I at least enjoyed the opening track? A lot of the music I found to be honestly kinda jarring and not in a good way. Usually a focal point of survival horror games is the use of sound design in order to create tension
column18: fear and a foreboding sense of danger
column19: whereas in this game it was mostly just some noise in the background
column20: bar a few encounters with enemies that triggered music.\n\nSo how about as an actual game. Well
column22: there was perhaps ONE enemy out of I believe the four that exist in the game that was even slightly threatening
column23: and even then I had no issue taking it down. The game throws ammunition at you
column24: as well as health items (painkillers). I should note here that I used painkillers once in the entire game
column25: when I intentionally allowed an enemy to hurt me to see if they even could attack or were non-hostile. For the rest of the game I stacked up probably around 15 or 16 bottles of painkillers that went unused because I never was even touched by an enemy. This is another key focus in survival horror games
column27: you're supposed to have a need to conserve ammo

column30: or involve just process of elimination. Figuring out how to progress for most of the game was simply a matter of walking around examining everything until you get the solution handed to you on a platter.\n\nI don't really want to comment on the graphics too much because one of the big appeals of this game was the graphic style

reviewText: If you enjoy both (1) the impressionistic look of early, primitive 3D graphics as seen on the PS1/Saturn/3DO; as well as (2) slower-paced, puzzle-sprinkled gameplay that is lighter on action but heavy on atmosphere, I think you'll love this game. If you think a game's price point should be based on how many hours you get out of the game, this game is gonna disappoint you.\n\nI personally value quality over quantity, and I felt like the heart" the developer put into this game was palpable. This game is more about atmosphere and narrative than mechanics; if that appeals to you

reviewText:
Back in 1995 is a retro-styled survival-horror game that takes most of its influence from a 1994 Japan-only 3DO horror game known as Dr. Hauzer and Silent Hill. The game has the sort of things you would expect from such an undertaking, such as fixed camera angles, limited supplies, tank controls. What may be a bit less predictable in the journey itself.

Now, let me first clarify something here and now; this game is not in the same league as the Resident Evil's and Silent Hill's of yesteryear. It doesn't even get in the remote ballpark of that level of quality during the 2-3 hour journey, and reminds me a lot more of the B-Tier horror game from that same era. I also feel I should preface this review with a mention that I am a horror enthusiast; I eat this genre right up. I played every Resident Evil and Silent Hill game through more than once ages ago, and have played more and more of the genre as time as gone on; I have played niche old titles ranging from Hungry Ghosts for the PS2 to Deep Fear on the Saturn, I've played all the Dead Space games and recently Night of the Sacrifice (Ikenie no Yoru) on the Wii, more recent indie horrors such as Left Alone and Dead Secret within the week, along with a ton of others. I have become more aware within the last few months I am beginning to run out of older horror games to play through; I have dug into the niche and the mostly forgotten, and I am almost done playing through every horror game that released before 2004, everything from the more well known Fatal Frame games to niche Korean-only PC releases. I think understanding where I'm coming from will help me explain my thoughts on this game.

Back in 1995 both succeeds and misses at what it is trying to be, and also provides an unexpected element that it also both succeeds and misses in. I'll talk about both elements here.

Firstly, as a retro horror game. The game actually does manage to capture that feel sometimes, particularly the feel of the B-Horror romps from yesteryear. I would put it at maybe the same quality as Chaos Break or Deep Fear, if you've played either of those. Games that have some flawed execution and rough edges, but can capture you with some well deployed curiosity. The game has four main segments, and each segment does manage to be more intriguing than the last and put new twists on the game to avoid becoming repetitive. The combat is super simple and maybe too easy for its own good; most of the enemies can be taken out pretty easily with just the crowbar you start off with, and while enemies attacks hurt, I found myself not very challenged by the game. There were a few puzzles that were a bit medium-easy in their difficulty for me, but were a bit of fun to mess around with.

The graphics look a bit worse than they should. Being able to alter the screen filter is good (I played the game with the CRT filter on but no noise, mostly), but the texture distortion is a bit much (textures distort and twist based on their perspective to the camera, which is an intended effect). It was very exaggerated and in some areas made the game look incredibly messy. The music went between being forgettable and a few nice tracks, but didn't really ever help the atmosphere, I felt. I get the game was going for a pre-PSX horror game sound style more similar to Alone in the Dark, Ecstatica, or the aftermentioned Dr. Hauzer, but I felt they could of easily gotten away with more atmospheric tracks and nobody would of given it any thought. The monsters aren't overused thankfully (there's only a handful of encounters in the game), and while there's only four different kinds they are used sparsely. I actually like most of them (the last two types especially), but the first monster type I could never find remotely scary or creepy, which is unfortunate (they look like fleshy Pacman ghosts to me).

Still, there's some interesting moments sprinkled throughout, some fun twists, a few moments that got me a bit to be startled or panicked, and on a whole I would say it was pretty alright. I think it's above the only other immediate indie comparisons I can give to this game, BlackSoul and Babysitter Bloodbath (some of the only retro-styled fixed camera angle indie horror games out there to this level). It's not just the most true to its roots, but the best executed of the three, in my opinion.

Which gets to a second element that many may not actually see coming about this game, I certainly didn't, which the game both hits the nail well on and doesn't. I'll spoiler tag this part, and would recommend if you plan to play the game and want to best experience it, not to read this, but I think it's important to mention. The game has a meta-game element.

The game a bit into it starts to do some tricks that sort of break the fourth wall, and they amp up towards the end of the game. We play as a character who is mentally stuck in 1995 and can't comprehend things that came out or happened after that year. Towards the end of the game, you think you might of finished the game (and I bet most will think so as the credits roll and you start the game from the beginning again), but if you play the beginning bit again he finds a more modern horror game-styled object which throws him off in how impossible it would be for back then, and then the game begins to disintegrate as he begins to realize we're, in fact, not in 1995. This element has a few moments that really do steal the show a bit, but unfortunately don't feel like they're pushed as far or as interestingly as they could of gone into. I also feel the moment with the creators comments could of been pushed to after the credits.

The story is pretty interesting, but let-down by a rather abrupt ending.

Still, I enjoyed the game actually. It both lived up to what I wanted it to be, didn't live up to it, and surprised me in ways I wasn't expecting. It's not a flawless game, but I do think there will be appeal for the rabid horror enthusiast that are like myself. It's not the truly excellent and complete return to old-school horror I think some want it to be, but if you go in with a bit of an open mind, some appreciation for the older B-Tier horror game, and don't mind a 2-3 hour experience, you might find some things to like here. It could of been executed better in certain areas, but what's there is still a pretty nice game which I feel I'm warming up to more a few hours after completing it. Not everything I wanted from it, but a nice experience that did give me some things I wasn't aware I wanted.

reviewText: I believe this project was primarily intended for a very specific audience: players with fond memories of 32-bit 3D games, who maintained a fondness for those rough, chunky polygon graphics well after the next wave of consoles arrived, and came to regard those limitations as having created a legitimate style all their own, no less valid than NES and SNES-style pixel art. I'm part of that group, though you may not be.\n\nEven if you are, you still may not get" this game. It's totally a style-over-substance work
date: but it's somewhat excusable for how well it nails the look of those fully rendered Playstation 3D adventures
voteText: Clock Tower: Ghost Head and Aconcagua. Even if it isn't comparable to the length or objective quality of those games. The characteristic "texture warping" of the PS1's 3D rendering is faithfully recreated: every surface seems to stretch and pulse with your every step

reviewText:
Memory Lane?

Full disclosure: review copy provided by the developer/publisher!


In my restless dreams, I see that game.

Silent Hill.

You promised you'd take me there again someday, Konami, you mother♥♥♥♥ingshitkicking♥♥♥♥♥sonsof♥♥♥♥♥es.

But you never did.
Well I'm alone there now...
In our 'special place'...


Waiting for someone to capture that spirit while actually doing something original.

Unfortunately, in spite of a commendable effort, Back in 1995 will not scratch that itch in a meaningful way.

The entire goal of this game is to milk them elusive “nostalgia feels,” and it does that to a shallow point; it manages to get the good, the bad, and the ugly aspects of classic survival horror. You are Kent, a dude just trying to get his daughter back? Or maybe get to a tower in the distance? It isn't clear. But after a near blow for blow Silent Hill 2 monologue you're thrust into the “action,” as it were.

If you've played any classic survivals it nails the look (something between Silent Hill and Alone in the Dark). Heck, if you haven't just check it out on Youtube, then come back.

So it nails that to a tee, right? The aesthetic, anyway. But it lacks the twisted soul. The first few enemies you encounter are like sadder, slower cousins of the fat dragon statues in the original Dark Souls (sans fire breath), and you can kill them with little effort – every strike interrupts their attack. As a matter of fact, with the exception of one behemoth beastie every critter (I counted three, maybe four?) is pretty easy to kill and not in the least intimidating. There are save points at every potential encounter, bullets everywhere, and an obscene amount of healing items... and far as I can tell no enemies ever respawned.

The sound design, where a game like this (SILENT HILL) should shine, falls super flat. Prepare your ears for the same footfalls for two to three hours, regardless of whether you're stepping on marble or rug or steel. It got to be very grating (nearly as grating as my single speed – SUNDAY STROLL).

Between the awkward fixed camera angles and white noise/scan lines I was nursing a mild headache by the end of my playthrough... that's what Back in 1995 is trying to emulate, yes (the look, not the headaches probably), but searching for a key in a cramped office space for thirty minutes when every turn results in a sudden camera change was pretty jarring.

“So they've screwed the pooch with story, horror, atmosphere... what about the puzzles? Silent Hill in particular is known for its (sometimes divisive) puzzles. Does Back in 1995 have any?” If by puzzle you mean searching through notes for a number combination then you are in luck! That is the extent of it.

I appreciate what the folks at Throw the warped code out were trying to do here, but it isn't enough to make a handful of flesh colored turd monsters wandering around a boring, lifeless environment compelling or spooky or good. I didn't care about my player character, I didn't care about getting to the tower or finding my daughter, because I was given no reason to care. I encountered three characters, each one less interesting than the next... I just don't know. Then the story just fizzles out in the lamest way and it's over in just under two hours (that includes 20, 30 minutes of looking for a key or number combination).

It wasn't good. It wallowed in the past and fell victim to the same pitfalls (and then some!) of classic survival horror without applying over 20 years of gaming knowledge and wisdom garnered since then. Back in 1995 feels like a half finished student product: bare bones with some potential, and too referential to have a distinct voice.

reviewText:
Back in 1995 seems to be polarizing for people due to its price vs gameplay hours at the moment.
I think that's a silly argument considering I've paid less for games I had more time with but they werent that FUN.
I had alot of fun throughout the game. It wasn't particularly hard, if anything for a survival horror game it was pretty easy but the dev really got the atmosphere down and I really had to stop and admire the low poly work. Really great work, as a fan of PS1 and PS2 level models I was really impressed by the modeling work and to see a horror game set in a modern office was pretty nice too. The music was good, not bad, not great, it was just good. Graphics wise it hit that exact spot the dev wanted to hit that much I can tell. Gameplay was smoother than some of the tanky surival horror games I've played actually. I'm excited for the upcoming english voice acting patch and very much so looking forward to any of the developers future work. Hopefully some of the other text issues can be fixed as I spotted a few issues with formatting in the game. I was a bit irritated that I couldn't play it on my actual CRT due to the way the developer forced 4:3 aspect ratio but it wasn't gamebreaking. Overall for 12 dollars I enjoyed my time and will probably play it again fairly soon.

8/10

Don't bother with this one."

reviewText:
I recommend this game, but for only a specific group of people.

If you're a huge fan of classic survival horror, you'll be able to ride the nostalgia train to the end. But there are flaws: the game provides no challenge in combat or puzzles, the monster designs are uninspired, the story has clever moments, but ultimately falls flat, and there are bugs, from ugly clipping to terrible camera angles, that are NOT related to the dated source material they're trying to imitate.

Overall, I wish they spent a few months to polish the game. Game design was definitely tighter than this back in 1995.

Also, $12 for a $5 game? I haven't felt this ripped off since I paid $12 for a Chumbawumba CD.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A really cool recreation of early 90s Playstation Survival Horror games. The game doesn't overstay it's welcome, with barely 3 hours playtime it is just long enough so that the gimmick doesn't grow tiresome.

Controls and camera angles could use some polish. It's tank controls of course, but it feels significantly jankier than Silent Hill 1 for example.

If you are nostalgic for the PS1 era, this is a cool little throwback! I hope to see more indies adopt this kind of low-fi aesthetic!

Oh one last thing: The game as a second ending - which kinda blew my mind!

reviewText: Well that was disappointing...\n\nI was somewhat really interested by Back In 1995. I grew up loving the PlayStation and the images from the Tomb Raider 1 to 5, MGS, Resident Evil 1 to 3, Silent Hill, FFVIII or Syphon Filter 1 to 3 are forever stuck in my mind. I love the aesthetic from this era. I think for certain genres, survival/horror in particular, it brings not only nostalgia, but a sense of weirdness and it is forcing you to imagine the details hidden in the pixelated mess that some of the most gruesome games of this time can show. So yeah, I dig the idea of this look. I still enjoy playing SH and RE1,2 and 3 to this day, and I'm still saying it holds up"...at least for SH and RE3. I say all that

voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I don't know that I could recommend this game enough.

Forget the price, even if the game is short, this is a dream for someone who loves classic horror games like myself. This was a fantastic 3-4 hour journey for me that didn't purely rely on nostalgia, but felt like it honestly could have been made in 1995. The graphics, the sound, the puzzles, the general eerieness...this has it all.

Also, if you think you've reached the end, don't stop playing, just push a button when it says to push and you'll get a shortened New Game + where the game is re-arranged and also has an amazing developer commentary over it explaining the origins and intentions of this game, and it was great to see this included for such a unique game.

I hope Mr. Takaaki can bring the game to other platforms as well, as I would buy it on all of them.

reviewText:
You can either watch it or read it!

*SPOILERS*
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fh-5-rEfTUI

Back In 1995 is a throwback to the survival horror classics of the 1990s - such as Resident Evil, Silent Hill, and Alone in the Dark.

I was really hyped for about a month waiting for it to come out. I didn't realize at the time it was going to be a one-man dev team, literally as I was downloading it, I was reading around on the game itself and came across that bit of information and all my hype basically disintegrated.

Having already, in my mind, dedicated the next two hours to old-school survival horror, I figured I'd give it a whirl.

First, this game supports quite a variety of controllers, which is sweet because this could've completed contradicted the point to the entire game - an homage to 90's survival horror".

The game then next give your CRT Effect options to simulate the crappy tvs a lot of us in our mid twenties plus grew up with. At first I was going to skip this effect
date: but ultimately opted for the CRT without noise
recommended: as old televisions have given my headaches my entire life.\n\nYou start off on the roof of a random building
voteText: you play as Kent as he is trying to get to a distant tower for unknown reasons.\n\nAs all 90s survival horror titles

column26: the briefcase here can only be opened when your find the note stating how to open it. I found the code first and got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ when it wouldn't work. Make sure you go down the hallway across the hall on the left hand side of the screen

column28: you get to the final area of the game. Which appears to be a luxury
column29: rooftop penthouse. This is where things begin to fall in place. After finding a crank to open a drawer - yes
column30: every survival horror game has to have a crank
column34: I do however fully except them - you start to find a lot of notes directed at your character Kent regarding his mental condition. Even going so far as to explain why there is no run option in the game. Kent's condition caused him to lose that ability as well as cognitive functions.\n\nHis mental condition is so unstable
column35: he believes he is still in the year 1995 - hence the title.\n\nWhen your reach your final destination
column36:
the tower in the distance. Kent decides he's had enough and chooses to end his suffering.

Which not to take away from the seriousness of the story... but he was on rooftops the entire game... he could've just jumped from anywhere and it would've had the same effect.

Some things I want to point out that I liked
-Tank controllers were spot on
-The monsters were original
column37:
the big one really reminded me of the final transformation of Berkin from Resident Evil 2.
-The overall feel was definitely 90s survival horror
-The save points were 90s computers
-Glitches were almost nonexistent
-Notes everywhere
column38:
just like Silent Hill and Resident Evil

Something I think need work
-some of the rooms were just a little empty
-I found a glitch that gave me unlimited shotgun ammo pickups
column39: in the hospital if you go back to the rooftop and return to the room with the briefcase
column40: the ammo will respawn.\n-Also a second glitch that I unlocked the "finish the game" and "get flashlight" achievements
column41: but somehow not "clear the first stage"
column44: "get pistol" that are all completed within the first 10 minutes of playing.\n-The enemies should be a little tougher
column46: they'll stop moving and as long as your keep attacking you'll kill them.\n-For an oldschool survival horror
column47: there's too many health items and too much ammo.\n-If there were to be a sequel
column48: which I really hope there is
column49: I'd recommend more story depth and more boss battles. The story worked just fine for this project.\n\nAfter the game was over
column50: it did something I did not all expect. After what I thought were the credits
column51: the game started over again without me doing anything. I retained all my weapons and items and figured
column53: lets run through it a little more". Upon entering the room with the telephone
column54: instead I found a flashlight. After thinking "what kind of creepypasta ♥♥♥♥ is this?" I turned it on and was met with some text
column55: then the font changed to a modern style.\n\nIntrigued
column56: I continued. I went back to the roof and there was a scaffolding that hadn't been there before. I then made my way rooftop to rooftop
column57: each covering an area I'd already been to.\n\nYou find various notes on your way back to the tower
column58: each one seeming to refer more to real life than the situation in the game itself. To me
column59: the entire game is merely a social commentary on retrogaming and those of us who simply can't let it go. Those of us w ho grasp to that nostalgia
column60: that first love we all had. It was new to us
column61: that's why it was so great. We were young and everything seemed to pop so much more. Then we grew up
column62: less and less felt new to us
column63: and that first love became a only a memory.\n\nMaking my way to the end
column64: this time taking only 5 minutes or so
column65: you're met with the final text "Am I no different than he
column66: who spent 20 years running away? Aren't we the same? From now on
column67: will I lead a meaningless life. Is there no way to reclaim my own life?"\n\nI feel like this is the developer saying
column68: 20 years ago when we were young
column69: the ones before us were attached to Atari games and Pac-man. They refused to move on no matter how much we tried to   convince them Playstation
column70: Resident Evil and Metal Gear Solid were better. They stopped moving forward
column71: as have we - and if we aren't moving forward
column72: we aren't progressing. We can't change the way nostalgia makes us feel.\n\nLoved the game
column73: hope there is a sequel or the dev makes another survival horror. Hell of an installment for

reviewText:
Not a game for everyone, thats for sure
If you are a fan of games like silent hill, house of the dead, resident evil, splatterhouse maybe ? then u good to go.
Living in a world that is infested with AAA games, is so refreshing to see a game like this getting released on steam.
Back in 1995 is a blend of all the good stuff of those old games, remember beating the last boss of HoTD? Facing tyrant in RE?  well you already know that graphics dont matter to enjoy a good game, and this is what back in 1995 brings us, a fun little experience that everyone left behind more than a decade ago,  the little details of the items, the spooky atmosphere makes this an enjoyable experience.

okay lets go

Gameplay: mix between SH1 and Alone in the dark 1 (DOS)
Lenght: 2 hours ~
Story: Not your avarege creepy game
Controls: Dudeee ♥♥♥♥ing epic


Yeah, this might not be a 10/10 but giving it a try is a must if you have fond memories of those games mentioned before.

reviewText: Big survival horror (RE/SH) fan here. Game has a lot of fundamental issues such as enemy AI (easily killed because they are stuck). Setting up the controller is a challenge as the default settings don't appear to work for anything other than possibly the PS4 controller. If you are using an XB1 controller you can start the game with KB/M and then go into the OPTIONS while IN THE GAME. There you can move around your controller settings. I believe I had the layout of the steam contoller and the Dpad layout of the DS4 and it was working alright. Your notes/info section only holds the info for the last item you inspected (which will include a locked door) and you can't view older files found. Ended up writing down puzzles with pen and paper (by my counter, there were only 2-3 puzzles). Using weapons other than the wrench was difficult in the sense that the function buttons didnt work correctly. The gun would randomly shoot when I only used the aim button, and I had to keep hitting aim on/off to shoot additional shots. Unless there is a hidden ending, I clocked 1 1/2 hours to finish the game. Going to hit my save file to check another few portions of the game out as 2 achievements are still hidden". Really let down so far with this game."

reviewText: This is tough to recommend as it feels unfinished with no real gameplay and no depth. This one had a lot of potential and they could've made something really special. Regardless, if you'd just like to briefly play a 3D game that looks like it came from the late 90's (silent hill, alone in the dark), then you'lll enjoy what it has to offer. Otherwise, stay away.
